title: Why President Obama picked Susan Rice
content:
Administration officials view Rice as something of an interventionist . | REUTERS Why Obama picked Rice
Since Rahm Emanuel packed his bags , President Barack Obama has recruited senior staffers who mirror his regimented , stay-in-your-lane style — but his choice of Susan Rice as National Security Adviser represents a shift back to the days when the West Wing brimmed with big ideas and even bigger egos .
In picking the lightning-rod U.N . Ambassador to replace the lower-key , process-driven Tom Donilon , Obama has broken with recent history to tap a colorful , ideological — and ultimately unpredictable — replacement , a move geared at energizing the White House and crafting a more coherent Obama Doctrine that moves beyond “ leading from behind . ”
Rice is a genuine wild card , people close to the situation say : Major questions loom about Rice ’ s capacity to deal with the congressional Republicans who blocked her appointment as secretary of state over the Benghazi fiasco and her ability to negotiate the claustrophobic West Wing .
Above all , it remains to be seen if Rice can sell the deeply cautious Obama team on a more interventionist , human-rights focused vision of U.S. power projection — an approach Rice has , for the moment , ruled out in Syria .
“ Despite the Benghazi thing , I expect Susan to be more of a public presence than Tom has been in terms of speeches , news briefings and even TV , ” said Tommy Vietor , a former NSC spokesman who worked for Donilon . “ She ’ s smart , she doesn ’ t mess around — and she ’ s tough . … There are not a lot of goofy , affable national security advisers . ”
Rice ’ s former spokesman at the U.N. Mark Kornblau painted a very different portrait of Rice than the quiet , publicity-averse Donilon , who carefully monitors the flow of information to Obama , a commander-in-chief who prefers his foreign policy to lay out all arguments rather than advocating any single one .
“ Susan , ” said Kornblau , “ has has the vision to set the right strategic course , the sheer will to grind it out to get there… Plus , she ’ s usually about two steps ahead of everyone else in the room . ”
Another former administration official put it more bluntly : “ She sometimes doesn ’ t play well with others , and that could shake things up a bit . ”
That might be just what Obama wants right now . Facing months of GOP intransigence and investigations , has recently made a series of appointments to his administration and the bench that reflect his personal preference — and need to fire up the Democratic base for the fights ahead — more than steering a middle course geared at attracting bipartisan support . And unlike other recent high-profile picks , he ’ s gone with someone in Rice who ’ s known more for independence than getting along .
“ Susan is the consummate public servant , a patriot who puts her country first . She is fearless , she is tough , she has a great tennis game and a pretty good basketball game , ” Obama said , flanked by Rice and Samantha Power , the anti-genocide crusader he tapped to replace the 48-year-old Rice at the United Nations .
“ Her brother is here , who I play with occasionally . It runs in the family , throwing the occasional elbow but hitting the big shot , ” alluding to Rice ’ s well-known pugnacity — which may put her at odds with Secretary of State John Kerry , who got the job she had been heading for .
CORRECTION : Corrected by : Nick Gass @ 06/06/2013 11:33 PM CORRECTION : An earlier version of this story misstated the position Susan Rice was serving in during the 1994 Rwanda genocide . She was an NSC staffer .
